item.title: Calculus

item.title: Computer Architecture
item.description: Courses [[lecture_notes/ECE120/ECE120 MOC|ECE120 MOC]] Books Intro to Computing Systems - Patt Wiki of Computer Architecture

item.title: ECE120 Lecture 1 - Abstraction and Representation
item.description: Abstraction Layer While constructing computers, we can use the idea of abstraction to make things easier: ![[lecture_notes/ECE120/images/Pasted image 20220414144524.png]] Representations Definition for representation The mapping from one form to another is called a representation.

item.title: ECE120 Lecture 14
item.description: Power of Two Checker How to check whether a number is the power of 2? It’s very easy for us human to do that because power of 2 has only one 1 bit in binary.

item.title: ECE120 Lecture 19
item.description: FSM Definition of FSM A FSM consists of five parts: Finite set of states Set of inputs Set of outputs(only dependent on state) Set of transition rules Methods for calculating outputs Digital FSM We implement FSM in digital system as sequential logic circuits.

item.title: ECE120 Lecture 2 - Numerical Representation
item.description: Unsigned [[lecture_notes/ECE120/ECE120 Lecture 1#Definition for representation|Representation]] In order to represent an integer, the computer uses base-2 numbers from mathematics (aka. binary).

item.title: ECE120 Lecture 20
item.description: Machine Models

item.title: ECE120 Lecture 21
item.description: graph TD; A--B; A--C; B--D; C--D;

item.title: ECE120 Lecture 22 - Memory
item.description: Storing Lots of Bits The computer weâ€™re going to design has a lot of places to store bits. Each place stores 32 bits.

item.title: ECE120 Lecture 23 - From FSM to Computer
item.description: FSM and Code Theoretically, finite state machines can solve any kinds of problems that computer language codes can solve. (Because computers are also finite state machines!

item.title: ECE120 Lecture 24 - The von Neumann Model
item.description: The von Neumann Model In 1946, John von Neumann invented a model for computer organization in which a computer comprises five parts.

item.title: ECE120 Lecture 7
item.description: Program Analysis Being able to read code is a necessary skill. In the real world, codes are often poorly commented (few people are interested in commenting their codes).

item.title: ECE120 Lecture 8
item.description: MOSFET All the digital electronics today use MOSFETs. There’re two kinds, named after the charge carrier. n(egative)-type p(ositive)-type !

item.title: ECON102 Lecture 7 - Trade
item.description: Production Possibilities Curve Production possibilities curve (PPC) shows the relationship between the maximum production of one good for a given level of production of another good.

item.title: ECON102 Lecture 8 - Externalities
item.description: Market Failures: Externalities There are important cases in which free markets fail to maximize social surplus. We call such cases market failures.
